item.title: About Us Section
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded:
• Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

About Us

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

We're a small team of developers based in Edinburgh who believe anybody can learn to code and go on to become a professional Software Engineer, regardless of background, experience, education, gender identity, sexual orientation, ethnicity or age.

Unfortunately, the tech industry still has a long way to go, with recent reports showing big players such as Facebook and Google still employ only 15% women and less than 5% people of colour.

The only way this is going to change is if we're proactive - rather than blaming the education system, or pointing the finger somewhere else, let's get out there and teach the next generation that coding is fun, rewarding and a great career choice for all!

We want to get people excited about technology, empower them with self-confidence, and give them all of the tools and resources they need to learn programming. That's all it takes - the software industry is merit-based, so as long as you can do the job, you'll get a job!

item.title: Level 1 Step 6
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded:
• Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Step 6

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Objective:

Add clickable icon links to your profiles on other social networks.

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget
Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

Inside your social links div, create links (also known as anchors – “a” tag) to your preferred social media profile(s).

Instead of making these links simple text, let’s make these icons – to do this, you’ll need an image or drawing of some sort for each.

A nice way to get consistent-looking icons is to use SVG, a format which is very efficient for line drawings (“vector graphics” for further reading).

If you browse to https://materialdesignicons.com, find the icon for your preferred social network and click “View SVG”, you’ll get a code which you can copy/paste into your “a” tag.

It’s also worth learning how to add comments in HTML, then adding one above the code for each link. This will help you identify them in the code, as the SVG path code will likely be an unfriendly string of numbers rather than anything human readable!

Outline Code
Example Code 

	

	
PODDuck Hufflepuff

	

		PODDuck Hufflepuff is a Software Engineer who works with students and anyone considering a career switch to help them learn the basics of coding.

		PODDuck believes anybody can learn to code and become a professional Software Engineer, regardless of background or experience.
	

	

		PODDuck is a Chartered IT Professional (CITP), a rigorous and demanding status recognised within the industry as a standard for integrity, professionalism and dedication. 

		As a visionary leader, PODDuck worked at the most prestigious firms around the world, and has now retired from regular work to travel the world preaching the benefits of software.
	

	

		Their contributions to the industry over the past decade have been featured in Forbes, New York Times, Mashable and Newsweek.

		PODDuck holds a PhD in Computer Science from Cambridge University.
	

	

		In addition to the high-flying career, PODDuck enjoys long walks in the bath and regular trips to Lush.
  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Example Screenshot:

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

item.title: Level 1 Intro Section
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded:
• Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Level 1

In this level we're going to start building a very simple "About Me" page summarising who you are and what you do - like a minimal version of LinkedIn, or an online business card!

We'll be using nothing but HTML in this level, introducing you to a small amount of the language originally released in 1993, now used by billions of websites!

item.title: Level 1 Complete Section
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded:
• Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Level Complete!

Congratulations, you've completed the first level of EdinCoder! You've learned a few common HTML tags and have created your own "About Me" page.

As it stands, this is already something which could be published to the internet and add value, telling the world a little bit about you. However, while HTML is great for adding structure (headings, sections, containers etc.) to text and image content, this same content can be so much more valuable if we style it well.

In Level 2 we'll start making our About Me page beautiful, adding CSS rules to add styling to the elements we've created here.

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget
Level 2

item.title: Level 2 Step 1
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded:
• Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Step 1

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Objective:

Choose one of the lovely Google Fonts instead of the default Times New Roman!

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget
Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

Click “Assets” in the bottom-left of your Level 2 CodePen, then “Fonts”.

Pick one and click “Copy @import”, then paste this into your CSS to make this font available to use.

You can then create a CSS selector which applies to the whole “body”, and add a rule to change the “font-family” to your chosen font.

Outline Code 
	@import url();
	body {
	}
Example Code 
	@import url("https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Montserrat:400,400i,700");
	body {
		font-family: Montserrat, sans-serif;
	}
  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Example Screenshot:

item.title: Level 2 Intro
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded:
• Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Level 2

In this level we're going to start adding style rules to the "About Me" page we created in Level 1.

We'll be using nothing but CSS in this level, paying close attention to the style rules for every HTML element on the page to style it neatly.

In CSS, style rules are applied to HTML elements using patterns called "CSS selectors" to identify which element(s) to style. This is why we added "class" properties to your HTML tags in Level 1. 

It may be worth quickly running through a guide on basic CSS selectors to understand how these work, or you can pick it up from the "Outline Code" tabs.

item.title: Level 2 Step 8
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded:
• Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Step 8

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Objective:

Center your social icon links and make them a bit bigger.

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget
Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

You should be able to center the icons by adding a simple “text-align” rule to the social-links “div”.

To make the icons bigger, first remove the inline “style” attribute from the SVG tags in your HTML .

You can then add a CSS rule which applies to all SVG tags in the social-links “div”, and apply a width and height of your choice.

One of the cool things about SVG is that you can even make other changes to the icons themselves from CSS – for example you can change the colour here using the “fill” attribute if you like!

Outline Code 
div.social-links {
}
div.social-links svg {
}
Example Code 
div.social-links {
    text-align: center;
}
div.social-links svg {
    width: 40px;
    height: 40px;
}
  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

item.title: Intro / Course What / How
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded:
• Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

What / How

We've broken this course down into levels, where each level assumes you're starting with code from the previous level, and builds upon what you've learned so far. As such, you should start at Level 1 and proceed through the levels in order; as you progress you'll quickly get to more challenging tasks.

Each level will specify the objectives of that level, and will show you a screenshot of our example app after completing that level. This is just to give you an idea of what to aim for - your version will have your own content and any personal style choices you choose to make!

Within each level there are a number of steps, with instructions and another screenshot of our example app for each. By default, only the instruction text is shown; this will often contain technical or semi-technical hints about how to achieve that step, as pointers of what you'll need to Google.

For each Level, you should create a new Pen in your CodePen account:

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Then write / modify code in that Pen for each step in the Level - the results of your changes should be immediately visible in the bottom CodePen window:

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

If you're struggling to understand what you need to do for a step and Google isn't helping, you've got a few options:

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget
  • Click the "Outline Code" tab - this should give you a little code as a starting point, but without giving you the complete code needed for the step.
  • Call over an EdinCoder team member to help out, or ask a fellow learner in case they've already passed this step and can help!
  • If nobody is free to help and you're keen to move on, click the "Example Code" tab to reveal the actual code we wrote for this step in the example app.
    This allows you to copy/paste working code rather than writing it yourself from scratch.

For each Level, you should create a new Pen in your CodePen account:<\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"a15c0f1","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/edincoder.tk\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/01\/2018-01-28-18_08_37-CodePen.png","id":201},"image_size":"custom","image_custom_dimension":{"width":"","height":"100"},"align":"left","image_box_shadow_box_shadow_type":"yes"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"4a9e10d","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Then write \/ modify code in that Pen for each step in the Level - the results of your changes should be immediately visible in the bottom CodePen window:<\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"7f887bf","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/edincoder.tk\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/01\/2018-01-28-18_11_59-EdinCoder-Level-1.png","id":203},"image_size":"full","align":"left","image_box_shadow_box_shadow_type":"yes"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"785dda8","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

If you're struggling to understand what you need to do for a step and Google isn't helping, you've got a few options:<\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"ae772b9","elType":"widget","settings":{"icon_list":[{"text":"Click the \"Outline Code\" tab - this should give you a little code as a starting point, but without giving you the complete code needed for the step.","icon":"fa fa-angle-right","_id":"f08aaa9","link":{"url":"","is_external":"","nofollow":""}},{"text":"Call over an EdinCoder team member to help out, or ask a fellow learner in case they've already passed this step and can help!","icon":"fa fa-angle-double-right","_id":"95a97ab","link":{"url":"","is_external":"","nofollow":""}},{"text":"If nobody is free to help and you're keen to move on, click the \"Example Code\" tab to reveal the actual code we wrote for this step in the example app.
This allows you to copy\/paste working code rather than writing it yourself from scratch.","icon":"fa fa-caret-right","_id":"1848f8d","link":{"url":"","is_external":"","nofollow":""}}],"space_between":{"unit":"px","size":20},"icon_align":"left","divider":"yes","_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"50","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"icon-list"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]

item.title: Training and courses
item.dc:creator: nat
item.content:encoded:
• Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Training and Courses

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

There are separate courses for each language. Chapters explain the concept and give you a bit of practice. You can play with sample code and see the results immediately. When you complete the exercise, you unlock the next chapter. After each course you can test your knowledge with a quiz.

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget
  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Courses are broken down into challenges. Each challenge gives you a new feature or command to learn and a piece of code that you can amend and see the changes on a little mobile phone on the website which displays your application. You are given a list of requests that your app must meet, and you need to change the code accordingly.

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget
  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Huge database of over 500 courses related with Computer Science prepared by universities from all over the world. You can learn programming, using software and acquire technical skills. These courses are a great source of theoretical knowledge, but they do not allow for much practice.

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget
  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Various courses about Tech and Coding. They focus on computer science rather than programming. Courses are not interactive but provide a lot of knowledge. Not a good place for someone who wants to discover basics of coding.

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget
  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Lessons start with short introduction article followed by videos which explain the code. In each chapter there are quizzes and practical challenges to test your progress. Lessons have great documentation where functions are commands are well explained.

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget
  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Step by step how to create your website. It explains also how to set up a cloud and turn it into a server to host your website. Great course for beginners, however lessons are based on videos and there is not much room for practice.

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget
  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Most of the courses are not free. Lessons are based on videos and they do not provide any practice or exercises.

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

Online Code Editors

During this course we used CodePen to write our code. Some of the resources have interactive code editors built in, but many will not. There are many online editors available, some of them are listed here.

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

CodePen

CodePen is the HTML/CSS/JavaScript editor we have been using in this course.

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

JsFiddle

Similar to CodePen, this is HTML/CSS/JavaScript editor

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

CodePad

While CodePad has a reduced user interface, it has many more languages available, including PHP, Python, and Ruby.

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

LiveWeave

Similar to CodePen and jsfiddle, this is a HTML/CSS/JavaScript editor

  • Edit Widget
  • Duplicate Widget
  • Remove Widget

CodeSandbox

This editor is for JavaScript web development and can be used with languages like React and Vue.

item.title: Level 1
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded:
Level 1

In this level we're going to start building a very simple "About Me" page summarising who you are and what you do - like a minimal version of LinkedIn, or an online business card!

We'll be using nothing but HTML in this level, introducing you to a small amount of the language originally released in 1993, now used by billions of websites!

Step 1

Objective:

Learn about the HTML <section> tag, and CSS classes. There's actually nothing visible at this point, we'll start adding content in the next step!

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

Create a <section> element to contain your profile content, and give it a sensible class name for future use

Outline Code
Example Code

Example Screenshot:

Step 2

Objective:

Add the first piece of content to your profile page - the one essential component on every public profile, a photo!

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

Add a profile image inside your profile section using the “img” tag.

You can either link to an image directly online (e.g. copy url of public profile photo on Facebook/LinkedIn etc.) or upload one to a free image hosting site like ImgBB.com.

You may want to add a “style” attribute to your “img” tag with a width value in pixels, to set the size to a reasonable size rather than displaying full size!

Optionally, you can learn what the “alt” attribute does for images and add one with a message of your choice.

Outline Code
Example Code

Example Screenshot:

Step 3

Objective:

Add a page heading displaying your name.

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

Add your name using an “h1” tag below your profile photo.

Outline Code
Example Code 

  

  
PODDuck Hufflepuff

Example Screenshot:

Step 4

Objective:

Add the core textual content of your profile page.

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

Write a few sentences about yourself inside paragraph tags (“p”). Imagine it’s a professional profile, CV blurb or LinkedIn summary!

Outline Code
Example Code 

	

	
PODDuck Hufflepuff

	

		PODDuck Hufflepuff is a Software Engineer who works with students and anyone considering a career switch to help them learn the basics of coding.

		PODDuck believes anybody can learn to code and become a professional Software Engineer, regardless of background or experience.
	

	

		PODDuck is a Chartered IT Professional (CITP), a rigorous and demanding status recognised within the industry as a standard for integrity, professionalism and dedication. 

		As a visionary leader, PODDuck worked at the most prestigious firms around the world, and has now retired from regular work to travel the world preaching the benefits of software.
	

	

		Their contributions to the industry over the past decade have been featured in Forbes, New York Times, Mashable and Newsweek.

		PODDuck holds a PhD in Computer Science from Cambridge University.
	

	

		In addition to the high-flying career, PODDuck enjoys long walks in the bath and regular trips to Lush.

Example Screenshot:

Step 5

Objective:

Learn about the HTML "div" tag, create an empty container for social links

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

After your bio paragraph(s), create a “div” tag with class “social-links” – we’ll put some links in this in the next step

Outline Code
Example Code 

	

	
PODDuck Hufflepuff

	

		PODDuck Hufflepuff is a Software Engineer who works with students and anyone considering a career switch to help them learn the basics of coding.

		PODDuck believes anybody can learn to code and become a professional Software Engineer, regardless of background or experience.
	

	

		PODDuck is a Chartered IT Professional (CITP), a rigorous and demanding status recognised within the industry as a standard for integrity, professionalism and dedication. 

		As a visionary leader, PODDuck worked at the most prestigious firms around the world, and has now retired from regular work to travel the world preaching the benefits of software.
	

	

		Their contributions to the industry over the past decade have been featured in Forbes, New York Times, Mashable and Newsweek.

		PODDuck holds a PhD in Computer Science from Cambridge University.
	

	

		In addition to the high-flying career, PODDuck enjoys long walks in the bath and regular trips to Lush.

Example Screenshot:

Step 6

Objective:

Add clickable icon links to your profiles on other social networks.

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

Inside your social links div, create links (also known as anchors – “a” tag) to your preferred social media profile(s).

Instead of making these links simple text, let’s make these icons – to do this, you’ll need an image or drawing of some sort for each.

A nice way to get consistent-looking icons is to use SVG, a format which is very efficient for line drawings (“vector graphics” for further reading).

If you browse to https://materialdesignicons.com, find the icon for your preferred social network and click “View SVG”, you’ll get a code which you can copy/paste into your “a” tag.

It’s also worth learning how to add comments in HTML, then adding one above the code for each link. This will help you identify them in the code, as the SVG path code will likely be an unfriendly string of numbers rather than anything human readable!

Outline Code
Example Code 

	

	
PODDuck Hufflepuff

	

		PODDuck Hufflepuff is a Software Engineer who works with students and anyone considering a career switch to help them learn the basics of coding.

		PODDuck believes anybody can learn to code and become a professional Software Engineer, regardless of background or experience.
	

	

		PODDuck is a Chartered IT Professional (CITP), a rigorous and demanding status recognised within the industry as a standard for integrity, professionalism and dedication. 

		As a visionary leader, PODDuck worked at the most prestigious firms around the world, and has now retired from regular work to travel the world preaching the benefits of software.
	

	

		Their contributions to the industry over the past decade have been featured in Forbes, New York Times, Mashable and Newsweek.

		PODDuck holds a PhD in Computer Science from Cambridge University.
	

	

		In addition to the high-flying career, PODDuck enjoys long walks in the bath and regular trips to Lush.

Example Screenshot:

Level Complete!

Congratulations, you've completed the first level of EdinCoder! You've learned a few common HTML tags and have created your own "About Me" page.

As it stands, this is already something which could be published to the internet and add value, telling the world a little bit about you. However, while HTML is great for adding structure (headings, sections, containers etc.) to text and image content, this same content can be so much more valuable if we style it well.

If you want to compare your completed code with our example, you can view the Level 1 live demo here, right click the page and click "View page source".

In Level 2 we'll start making our About Me page beautiful, adding CSS rules to add styling to the elements we've created here.

Level 2

Add a profile image inside your profile section using the "img" tag.

You can either link to an image directly online (e.g. copy url of public profile photo on Facebook/LinkedIn etc.) or upload one to a free image hosting site like ImgBB.com.

You may want to add a "style" attribute to your "img" tag with a width value in pixels, to set the size to a reasonable size rather than displaying full size!

Optionally, you can learn what the "alt" attribute does for images and add one with a message of your choice.

PODDuck Hufflepuff

  
	

		PODDuck Hufflepuff is a Software Engineer who works with students and anyone considering a career switch to help them learn the basics of coding.

		PODDuck believes anybody can learn to code and become a professional Software Engineer, regardless of background or experience.
	

	

		PODDuck is a Chartered IT Professional (CITP), a rigorous and demanding status recognised within the industry as a standard for integrity, professionalism and dedication. 

		As a visionary leader, PODDuck worked at the most prestigious firms around the world, and has now retired from regular work to travel the world preaching the benefits of software.
	

	

		Their contributions to the industry over the past decade have been featured in Forbes, New York Times, Mashable and Newsweek.

		PODDuck holds a PhD in Computer Science from Cambridge University.
	

	

		In addition to the high-flying career, PODDuck enjoys long walks in the bath and regular trips to Lush.

Add clickable icon links to your profiles on other social networks.

"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"21e3fa2","elType":"widget","settings":{"tabs":[{"tab_title":"Instructions","tab_content":"

Inside your social links div, create links (also known as anchors - "a" tag) to your preferred social media profile(s).

Instead of making these links simple text, let's make these icons - to do this, you'll need an image or drawing of some sort for each.

A nice way to get consistent-looking icons is to use SVG, a format which is very efficient for line drawings ("vector graphics" for further reading).

If you browse to https://materialdesignicons.com, find the icon for your preferred social network and click "View SVG", you'll get a code which you can copy/paste into your "a" tag.

It's also worth learning how to add comments in HTML, then adding one above the code for each link. This will help you identify them in the code, as the SVG path code will likely be an unfriendly string of numbers rather than anything human readable!

Congratulations, you've completed the first level of EdinCoder! You've learned a few common HTML tags and have created your own "About Me" page.

As it stands, this is already something which could be published to the internet and add value, telling the world a little bit about you. However, while HTML is great for adding structure (headings, sections, containers etc.) to text and image content, this same content can be so much more valuable if we style it well.

If you want to compare your completed code with our example, you can view the Level 1 live demo here, right click the page and click "View page source".

In Level 2 we'll start making our About Me page beautiful, adding CSS rules to add styling to the elements we've created here.

item.title: Home
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded:
Start Coding Learning Resources

Level 1

Learn HTML basics to build a simple "About Me" webpage

Level 2

Learn CSS fundamentals and make the web beautiful

Level 3

Learn basic JavaScript to start making things interactive

Course

"Learning to code is the single best thing anyone can do to get the most out of the amazing future in front of us." - Marc Andreessen

The course we've built is designed to be used as learning material for a short (~2 hours) workshop run by the edincoder team.

No programming experience is required, and nothing but a web browser is needed. Starting with Level 1, we will guide you through the process of building your own webpage, using online code editor Codepen to write code and immediately see the results.

Along with teaching you how the basics of the web work, we're also trying to teach you how to learn by yourself. One of the great things about software development is that there is a huge amount of free, high quality documentation and learning material available online, so rather than telling you exactly what to do, we give you hints and expect you to Google for the specifics you need for each step!

At the end of the workshop, we'll give you a handout with credentials for your own bit of webspace; a place to host your own website so it's online on the internet and accessible to the world. We'll then show you how to upload the code you've written in Codepen to this webspace, so you can show off your creation!

Tech

About Us

We're a small team of developers based in Edinburgh who believe anybody can learn to code and go on to become a professional Software Engineer, regardless of background, experience, education, gender identity, sexual orientation, ethnicity or age.

Unfortunately, the tech industry still has a long way to go, with recent reports showing big players such as Facebook and Google still employ only 15% women and less than 5% people of colour.

The only way this is going to change is if we're proactive - rather than blaming the education system, or pointing the finger somewhere else, let's get out there and teach the next generation that coding is fun, rewarding and a great career choice for all!

We want to get people excited about technology, empower them with self-confidence, and give them all of the tools and resources they need to learn programming. That's all it takes - the software industry is merit-based, so as long as you can do the job, you'll get a job!

Kim

I graduated from the University of Dundee last year with a degree in Applied Computing. I've been coding since I was a child and fell in love with the way we could manipulate data and interact with technology so I decided I wanted to make a career out of that. I've been working as a full time Software Engineer for about 7 months now, and I love the field because I feel like I'm always growing and learning something new.

Chiquita

I am an engineer of Geodesy and Cartography. I became keen on programming when I released how it can simplify my life. The basics of programming helped during my masters course. You don't need to be a programmer to make use of coding, it is now applicable everywhere!

Natasha

I graduated Edinburgh University in 2016 with a degree in maths. At that point I hadn't done much coding of my own and didn't think I would be able to make a career out of it. I've now been a software developer for 1 1/2 years, and I really believe that coding can be for everyone, regardless of your background.

Andrew

I'm a software architect / engineer / product manager with a passion for the web and over 10 years experience. I got into web development as a teenager making MySpace themes for friends, then realised the skills I'd learned were valuable and started doing freelance web development work instead of going to school! Solving problems is what really makes me tick; technology is just a conduit for efficient solutions.

\"Learning to code is the single best thing anyone can do to get the most out of the amazing future in front of us.\"\u00a0<\/em>-\u00a0Marc Andreessen<\/em><\/p>","align":"center","text_color":"#2a282b","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":"19"},"typography_font_family":"PT Sans","typography_font_weight":"normal","_padding":{"unit":"%","top":"0","right":"20","bottom":"0","left":"20","isLinked":false},"_padding_mobile":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"0","left":"0","isLinked":false},"_background_background":"classic"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"90a1c12","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

The course we've built is designed to be used as learning material for a short (~2 hours) workshop run by the edincoder team.<\/p>

No programming experience is required, and nothing but a web browser is needed. Starting with Level 1, we will guide you through the process of building your own webpage, using online code editor Codepen<\/b>\u00a0to write code and immediately see the results.<\/p>

Along with teaching you how the basics of the web work, we're also trying to teach you how to learn by yourself.<\/i>\u00a0One of the great things about software development is that there is a huge amount of free, high quality\u00a0documentation and<\/span>\u00a0<\/span>learning material available online, so rather than telling you exactly what to do, we give you hints and expect you to Google for the specifics you need for each step!<\/span><\/p>

At the end of the workshop, we'll give you a handout with credentials for your own bit of webspace; a place to host your own website so it's online on the internet and accessible to the world. We'll then show you how to upload the code you've written in Codepen to this webspace, so you can show off your creation!<\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"7276b250","elType":"section","settings":{"background_background":"none","padding":{"unit":"px","top":"70","right":"0","bottom":"70","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"69667049","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"52ba76c1","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Tech","align":"center","title_color":"#ff5a03","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":43},"typography_font_family":"Roboto widget","settings":{"title":"About fa-heart","primary_color":"#00c0dd","size":{"unit":"px","size":23},"_padding":{"unit":"px","top":"10","right":"0","bottom":"20","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"icon"},{"id":"693ac478","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

We're a small team of developers based in Edinburgh who believe anybody<\/b> can learn to code and go on to become a professional Software Engineer, regardless of background, experience, education, gender identity, sexual orientation,\u00a0ethnicity or age.<\/p>

Unfortunately, the tech industry still has a long way to go, with recent reports showing big players such as Facebook and Google still employ only 15% women and less than 5% people of colour.<\/p>

The only way this is going to change is if we're proactive - rather than blaming the education system, or pointing the finger somewhere else, let's get out there and teach the next generation that coding is fun, rewarding and a great career choice for all!<\/span><\/p>

We want to get people excited<\/i> about technology, empower<\/i> them with self-confidence, and give them all of the tools and resources they need\u00a0to learn programming. That's all it takes - the software industry is merit-based, so as long as you can do the job, you'll get a job!<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"a20e471","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"divider"},{"id":"379cc59","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20"},"elements":[{"id":"a5ea2cc","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":20,"content_position":"center"},"elements":[{"id":"937bc2e","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/edincoder.tk\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/01\/Kim1.jpg","id":537},"image_size":"medium","space":{"unit":"%","size":80},"image_border_radius":{"unit":"%","top":"50","right":"50","bottom":"50","left":"50","isLinked":true},"image_box_shadow_box_shadow_type":"yes","image_box_shadow_box_shadow":{"horizontal":0,"vertical":0,"blur":20,"spread":0,"color":"rgba(0,0,0,0.5)"}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"}],"isInner":true},{"id":"8f9424a","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":80,"content_position":"center","padding":{"unit":"px","top":"17","right":"20","bottom":"0","left":"20","isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"96744d2","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Kim","title_color":"#ff5a03"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"52a4af8","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

I graduated from the University of Dundee last year with a degree in Applied Computing. I've been coding since I was a child and fell in love with the way we could manipulate data and interact with technology so I decided I wanted to make a career out of that. I've been working as a full time Software Engineer for about 7 months now, and I love the field because I feel like I'm always growing and learning something new.<\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":true},{"id":"55ab4fc","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20"},"elements":[{"id":"2aad5bc","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":80,"content_position":"center","padding":{"unit":"px","top":"17","right":"20","bottom":"0","left":"20","isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"c3f648c","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Chiquita","title_color":"#ff5a03"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"a2ff642","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

You don't need to be a programmer to make use of coding, it is now applicable everywhere!<\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true},{"id":"780552b","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":20,"content_position":"center"},"elements":[{"id":"806cfbc","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/edincoder.tk\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/01\/Chiquita2.jpg","id":540},"image_size":"medium","space":{"unit":"%","size":80},"image_border_radius":{"unit":"%","top":"50","right":"50","bottom":"50","left":"50","isLinked":true},"image_box_shadow_box_shadow_type":"yes","image_box_shadow_box_shadow":{"horizontal":0,"vertical":0,"blur":20,"spread":0,"color":"rgba(0,0,0,0.5)"}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":true},{"id":"8e23fa9","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20"},"elements":[{"id":"1f6545c","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":20,"content_position":"center"},"elements":[{"id":"c64c6ea","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/edincoder.tk\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/01\/Natasha1.jpg","id":538},"image_size":"medium","space":{"unit":"%","size":80},"image_border_radius":{"unit":"%","top":"50","right":"50","bottom":"50","left":"50","isLinked":true},"image_box_shadow_box_shadow_type":"yes","image_box_shadow_box_shadow":{"horizontal":0,"vertical":0,"blur":20,"spread":0,"color":"rgba(0,0,0,0.5)"}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"}],"isInner":true},{"id":"d6ce796","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":80,"content_position":"center","padding":{"unit":"px","top":"17","right":"20","bottom":"0","left":"20","isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"521ac8c","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Natasha","title_color":"#ff5a03"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"af3abfa","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

I graduated Edinburgh University in 2016 with a degree in maths. At that point I hadn't done much coding of my own and didn't think I would be able to make a career out of it. item.title: Level 2
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded:
Level 2

In this level we're going to start adding style rules to the "About Me" page we created in Level 1.

We'll be using nothing but CSS in this level, paying close attention to the style rules for every HTML element on the page to style it neatly.

In CSS, style rules are applied to HTML elements using patterns called "CSS selectors" to identify which element(s) to style. This is why we added "class" properties to your HTML tags in Level 1. 

It may be worth quickly running through a guide on basic CSS selectors to understand how these work, or you can pick it up from the "Outline Code" tabs.

Step 1

Objective:

Choose one of the lovely Google Fonts instead of the default Times New Roman!

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

Click “Assets” in the bottom-left of your Level 2 CodePen, then “Fonts”.

Pick one and click “Copy @import”, then paste this into your CSS to make this font available to use.

You can then create a CSS selector which applies to the whole “body”, and add a rule to change the “font-family” to your chosen font.

Outline Code 
	@import url();
	body {
	}
Example Code 
	@import url("https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Montserrat:400,400i,700");
	body {
		font-family: Montserrat, sans-serif;
	}

Example Screenshot:

Step 2

Objective:

Replace the default white background with a full screen background image.

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

First you’ll need to find a suitable image which is high resolution and free to use – the CodePen Assets tool has some decent ones!

If you can’t find something you like, you can always find one elsewhere online (e.g. pexels.com) and upload it to a free image host (e.g. imgbb.com).

Once you’ve got an image URL, use the background-image and background-size CSS rules to make it cover the whole body section.

Outline Code 
	@import url();
	body {
	}
Example Code 
	@import url("https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Montserrat:400,400i,700");
	body {
		font-family: Montserrat, sans-serif;
		background-image: url("https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1506377585622-bedcbb027afc?ixlib=rb-0.3.5&q=85&fm=jpg&crop=entropy&cs=srgb&ixid=eyJhcHBfaWQiOjE0NTg5fQ&s=a9e6f90ef3dc023c4c40a78153993762");
		background-size: cover;
	}

Example Screenshot:

Step 3

Objective:

Add a solid background to make the profile text readable.

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

Give the profile content section a white background, so the black text is readable despite the body background image.

 

Outline Code 
section.profile-bio {
}
Example Code 
section.profile-bio {
    background: white;
}

Example Screenshot:

Step 4

Objective:

Position the profile content section in the middle of the page as a boxed section.

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

Give the profile content section a “width” of only 35% of the page, and center it horizontally;

To center a block-level element (like “section”, “div” etc.) horizontally, the easiest way is to give it a margin value of “auto”.

Outline Code 
section.profile-bio {
}
Example Code 
section.profile-bio {
    background: white;
    width: 35%;
    margin: auto;
}

Example Screenshot:

Step 5

Objective:

Make the profile box look nicer!

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

Give the profile section 60px “padding”, 100px “margin-top”, and a “border-radius” of 4px to give it subtly rounded corners.

Outline Code 
section.profile-bio {
}
Example Code 
section.profile-bio {
    background: white;
    width: 35%;
    margin: auto;
    padding: 60px;
    margin-top: 100px;
    border-radius: 4px;
}

Example Screenshot:

Step 6

Objective:

Make your profile photo smaller, and circular.

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

Add style properties to set the width and height to 150px.

If this doesn’t change the size of the image, you’ll probably added an inline style rule to the “img” tag itself in Level 1 – remove this.

You’ll then want to set a “border-radius” of 50% – essentially giving it “rounded corners”, but where the corners are so round it becomes circular!

Outline Code 
img.podduck-image {
}
Example Code 
img.podduck-image {
    width: 150px;
    height: 150px;
    border-radius: 50%;
}

Example Screenshot:

Step 7

Objective:

Position your profile photo so it is horizontally centered, and hovers half above the profile section.

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

To do this, you’ll first need to add a “position: relative” rule to the profile section so we can position elements inside it.

Then, we can give the image a “position: absolute” rule and specify its position using the “top” and “left” CSS rules.

Since we’ve made the image circular with 150px diameter, you can give it a “top” position of -75px and it will be positioned half above the profile section.

To center it horizontally, we need to make use of the “calc()” function for the “left” value, as we want to position it at the halfway point (50%), minus 75px.

Outline Code 
section.profile-bio {
}
img.podduck-image {
}
Example Code 
section.profile-bio {
    position: relative;
}
img.podduck-image {
    position: absolute;
    top: -75px;
    left: calc(50% - 75px);
}

Example Screenshot:

Step 8

Objective:

Center your social icon links and make them a bit bigger.

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

You should be able to center the icons by adding a simple “text-align” rule to the social-links “div”.

To make the icons bigger, first remove the inline “style” attribute from the SVG tags in your HTML .

You can then add a CSS rule which applies to all SVG tags in the social-links “div”, and apply a width and height of your choice.

One of the cool things about SVG is that you can even make other changes to the icons themselves from CSS – for example you can change the colour here using the “fill” attribute if you like!

Outline Code 
div.social-links {
}
div.social-links svg {
}
Example Code 
div.social-links {
    text-align: center;
}
div.social-links svg {
    width: 40px;
    height: 40px;
}

Example Screenshot:

Level Complete!

Congratulations, you've completed the second level of EdinCoder!

You've learned enough CSS to start making things look how you want, and we've made your "About Me" page much more appealing to visitors. 

If you want to compare your completed code with our example, you can view the Level 2 live demo here.

In Level 3 we'll add a couple more elements to our About Me page, with a bit more CSS, then introduce you to JavaScript to start making things interactive.

Level 3

item.title: Level 3
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded:
Level 3

In this level we're going to add a bit more functionality to the "About Me" page, with a list of skills and a "Hire Me" call to action button.

We'll be adding a bit more HTML, some more CSS to style the new elements, and writing our first bit of JavaScript to make the button functional.

Step 1

Objective:

Add a sub-heading to the page.

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

Add a few words summarising what you do and where you are to a subtitle element (e.g. “h3” tag) below your name in the HTML.

Outline Code
Example Code 
	
Software Engineer, Educator and Life Coach in Edinburgh, UK

Example Screenshot:

Step 2

Objective:

Add a button to the page.

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

Add an HTML “button” tag below the title/subtitle, with the text “Hire Me” displayed on the button and an id of “hireme” so we can reference this later.

Outline Code
Example Code

Example Screenshot:

Step 3

Objective:

Add a list of your skills to the page.

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

Use the HTML “ul” tag to add a bullet-point list of your top 3-5 skills, just before the social links section.

Outline Code 
	
    
        
  •
Example Code 
	
    
        
  • Software
    • 
        
  • Leadership
    • 
        
  • Flying
    • 
        
  • Bathing
    •

Example Screenshot:

Step 4

Objective:

Add styling to the title and subtitle and reduce margins on the profile box.

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

Update the existing padding rule for the profile-bio section we added in an earlier stage so it has 60px at the top and bottom, and only 30px on the sides.

Give both the “h1” and “h3” tags a text-align property to center them.

Then give the “h1” a text-transform to capitalise it, and a letter-spacing of 2px as a design element.

To help bring the title together as one entity, make the bottom margin only 10px for the “h1”, 30px for the “h3” and make the top margin 0 for the “h3”.

Lastly, change the text colour for both headings to #333 – this is a dark grey which will fit in with the rest of the styles better than the default black.

Outline Code 
	section.profile-bio {
	}
	section.profile-bio h1,
	section.profile-bio h3 {
	}
	section.profile-bio h1 {
	}
	section.profile-bio h3 {
	}
Example Code 
	section.profile-bio {
		padding: 60px 30px;
	}
	section.profile-bio h1,
	section.profile-bio h3 {
		text-align: center;
		color: #333;
	}
	section.profile-bio h1 {
		text-transform: uppercase;
		letter-spacing: 2px;
		margin-bottom: 10px;
	}
	section.profile-bio h3 {
		margin-top: 0;
		margin-bottom: 30px;
	}

Example Screenshot:

Step 5

Objective:

Add styling to the "Hire Me" button to make it a real Call to Action (CTA).

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

There are a few properties we’ve applied to the this button to make it look good – let’s go through them one by one:

    display: block – this allows us to give the button other block-level properties (such as width)

    width: 70% – so it’s not the full width of the section

    margin: 20px auto – a bit of space above/below the button, and automatic margins on left/right so it will be centered

    padding: 10px – this gives the button a bit of bulk so it looks more like a button than just a rectangle with text in it

    border: none – HTML buttons come with ugly thick borders by default, so we’re removing this for the aesthetic benefit

    border-radius: 4px – rounded corners; it’s a button.

    background-color: #666 – a dark grey which won’t jump out at you but is clear and legible

    color: white – white text on grey background; classy

Outline Code 
	button#hireme {
	}
Example Code 
	button#hireme {
		display: block;
		width: 70%;
		margin: 20px auto;
		padding: 10px;
		border: none;
		border-radius: 4px;
		background-color: #666;
		color: white;
	}

Example Screenshot:

Step 6

Objective:

Resize paragraphs of text to match button width, and reduce font size a bit.

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

For all “p” tags inside the profile section, set the width and margin to match the Hire Me button (70%, 20px/auto), and specify a font size of 14px.

Outline Code 
	section.profile-bio p {
	}
Example Code 
	section.profile-bio p {
		width: 70%;
		margin: 20px auto;
		font-size: 14px;
	}

Example Screenshot:

Step 7

Objective:

Re-style the "top skills" bullet-points list into a subtle horizontal list.

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

We’re going to fairly radically change how this bullet-point list is displayed – in fact we’re going to make it a horizontal list with no bullets at all!

    As such, there’s a few properties to set again; let’s run through them explaining what each does:

    display: flex; – this is a very flexible new CSS property which lets you define how an item will grow or shrink to fit the space available in its container

    justify-content: space-between; – this tells the flex layout to justify all child elements by varying the space between each element

    width: 70%; – set the width of this “ul” tag (which we’re now treating as if it were just a block-level container) to match the paragraphs above it

    margin: 0 auto 20px auto; – set the margins of this horizontal “ul” so it’s centered horizontally like the paragraphs, but also has 20px margin below it to push the social icons away

    padding: 0; – “ul” comes by default with some hefty margins set, so we want to remove these as we’re taking more control over how it’s displayed

    list-style-type: none; – get rid of the bullet points! “ul” is actually a very flexible element which should be used whenever you’re representing a list of items, not just for bullet points!

    font-size: 14px; – reduce font size to match paragraphs

    color: #999; – make text a light grey, so these skills are just a very unobtrusive bit of extra info

Outline Code 
	ul.skills {
	}
Example Code 
	ul.skills {
		display: flex;
		justify-content: space-between;
		width: 70%;
		margin: 0 auto 20px auto;
		padding: 0;
		list-style-type: none;
		font-size: 14px;
		color: #999;
	}

Example Screenshot:

Step 8

Objective:

Make the "Hire Me" button and the social links change colour when you hover over them.

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

For both of these you’ll want to use the :hover pseudo-selector to apply the rule only when you’re hovering the mouse over the elements.

For the button, it’ll simply be change the background colour – I’d go for a nice blue, something like #6688BB

For the social links you’ll want a :hover rule which targets any SVG tag in the social-links container, and sets the “fill” property to your chosen colour

Outline Code 
	button#hireme:hover {
	}
	div.social-links svg:hover {
	}
Example Code 
	button#hireme:hover {
		background-color: #6688BB;
	}
	div.social-links svg:hover {
		fill: #6688BB;
	}

Example Screenshot:

Step 9

Objective:

Make the "Hire Me" button trigger an email message to you when clicked.

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

Create a JavaScript function and assign it to a helpfully-named variable, e.g. “setupHireMeButtonClick”.

Inside that function, use document.getElementById to get your Hire Me button element, and assign this to a variable, e.g. “hiremeButton”.

Call “addEventListener” on the hire me button to add an event listener of type “click” to that button – the listener will be another function, to be called whenever the button is clicked.

Inside your event listener, use “createElement” to create a link element (“a” tag, as links are technically “anchors”), and assign that to a variable.

Set the “href” property of the link to “mailto:YOUREMAIL” (where YOUREMAIL is your email address).

Set the “target” property of the link to “_blank”. This tells your web browser to open the link in a new tab/window.

Finally, call “click()” on the link – this will trigger the browser functionality for clicking “mailto:” links, which should open an email client window!

Now we’ve got a function (“setupHireMeButtonClick”) which sets up the click event handler on the button when run, but we still need to run that function!

However, we need to wait until the webpage has loaded before trying to do this, else your web browser might not have loaded all of the HTML yet.

To do this, we can add an event listener on the document itself, listening for the event “DOMContentLoaded” which fires when the whole HTML page has been loaded and processed by the browser. This event listener should call our “setupHireMeButtonClick” function to set up the button click handler.

Outline Code 
	var setupHireMeButtonClick = function() {
		var hiremeButton;
		hiremeButton.addEventListener("click", function(e) {
		}, false);
	};
	document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', setupHireMeButtonClick, false);
Example Code 
	var setupHireMeButtonClick = function() {
		var hiremeButton = document.getElementById('hireme');
		hiremeButton.addEventListener("click", function(e) {
			var hiremeMailtoLink = document.createElement('a');
			hiremeMailtoLink.href = "mailto:help@edincoder.tk";
			hiremeMailtoLink.target = "_blank";
			hiremeMailtoLink.click();
		}, false);
	};
	document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', setupHireMeButtonClick, false);

Example Screenshot:

Level Complete!

Congratulations, you've completed the third level of EdinCoder!

You've learned a few more HTML tags, gained confidence with CSS and written your first code in JavaScript.

If you want to compare your completed code with our example, you can view the Level 3 live demo here.

Your "About Me" page is now reasonably slick and functional - something which is worth publishing online!

In the next step, we'll introduce you to how to publish a website online, and give you your own hosting space where you can upload your "About Me" page!

Publish

item.title: Intro
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded:
Intro

Welcome to EdinCoder! To complete this course you'll need the following:

  • A computer with a web browser (preferably Google Chrome)
  • An account on CodePen.io (click here to sign up for free)
  • An open mind and willingness to Google lots!

The general idea of this is that we're going to be working together to create personalised versions of a few pre-made web page ideas, building them up step by step and learning how the code works at each level.

"If you can programme a washing machine, you can program a website" - CR

Course Objectives

This course aims to provide you with the following:

  • An understanding of the different elements which make up a website, and how these work together.
  • Hands on experience of writing code to build your own website from scratch.
  • Experience publishing your own website online on a typical web hosting setup.
  • Recommended resources for further learning and practice.

World Wide Web Basics

When we type a website URL into our web browser and hit enter, what's actually happening? 

Firstly, our browser needs to a make a request to DNS (Domain Name System) servers to find out the IP (Internet Protocol) address of the website. Although this sounds complicated, it's really just a bit like looking a phone number up in a phone book - we make a request for the domain name and get given an IP address back.

Using this IP address, we can now make a request to that address to fetch the website content. This IP address could be the location of a computer anywhere in the world (known as a "Web Server"), usually run by an organisation. The web server will then reply by sending us back the code of the website, which our web browser processes to display the website on our screen. 

All web pages are created first by writing some HTML (HyperText Markup Language). This markup can be considered the "structural layer" of a website - it's a bit like putting down the foundations of a house. Rather than just having a large block of text, HTML allows you to define sections, headings, paragraphs, tables, add images to the page and links to other web addresses.

In order to make websites look more attractive rather than just boring old text and images, we can use CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) to specify styles we want to apply to our HTML elements. This can involve adjusting fonts, alignment, borders, colours, backgrounds, spacing and so on - it's very flexible and gives you complete control over the design of the page. Much like an artist with a blank sheet of paper, you can produce pretty much anything you want!

If you want to make your website more interactive for users - maybe adding buttons, making elements move on the page, or implementing complex functionality like a zoomable map or a 3D game - you can do this using JavaScript. 

Start Coding

item.title: Course
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded:
What / How

We've broken this course down into levels, where each level assumes you're starting with code from the previous level, and builds upon what you've learned so far. As such, you should start at Level 1 and proceed through the levels in order; as you progress you'll quickly get to more challenging tasks.

Each level will specify the objectives of that level, and will show you a screenshot of our example app after completing that level. This is just to give you an idea of what to aim for - your version will have your own content and any personal style choices you choose to make!

Within each level there are a number of steps, with instructions and another screenshot of our example app for each. By default, only the instruction text is shown; this will often contain technical or semi-technical hints about how to achieve that step, as pointers of what you'll need to Google.

For each Level, you should start with your code from the previous level, so use the "Fork" button to copy the previous Pen in your CodePen account:

Then write / modify code in that Pen for each step in the Level - the results of your changes should be immediately visible in the bottom CodePen window:

If you're struggling to understand what you need to do for a step and Google isn't helping, you've got a few options:

  • Click the "Outline Code" tab - this should give you a little code as a starting point, but without giving you the complete code needed for the step.
  • Call over an EdinCoder team member to help out, or ask a fellow learner in case they've already passed this step and can help!
  • If nobody is free to help and you're keen to move on, click the "Example Code" tab to reveal the actual code we wrote for this step in the example app.
    This allows you to copy/paste working code rather than writing it yourself from scratch.

Example Step 1

Objective:

Write a couple of sentences inside a simple HTML building block.

Instructions Outline Code Example Code Instructions

In this section we’ll provide instructions for what to do in this step, with a bit of explanation about why we’re doing this.

Usually this will include one or two technical references – small snippets of code as part of the instructions. These are intended to give you hints for what to google to find examples or tutorials online to read through and copy/paste from.

For example: “Create a section element with a suitable “class” attribute, and write a couple of sentences inside that section in paragraph (p) tags.”

Outline Code
Example Code 

  
Example paragraph text.

  
Full sentence of text!

Example Screenshot:

Level 1

We've broken this course down into levels, where each level assumes you're starting with code from the previous level, and builds upon what you've learned so far. As such, you should start at Level 1 and proceed through the levels in order; as you progress you'll quickly get to more challenging tasks.

Each level will specify the objectives of that level, and will show you a screenshot of our example app after completing that level. This is just to give you an idea of what to aim for - your version will have your own content and any personal style choices you choose to make!

Within each level there are a number of steps, with instructions and another screenshot of our example app for each. By default, only the instruction text is shown; this will often contain technical or semi-technical hints about how to achieve that step, as pointers of what you'll need to Google.

For each Level, you should start with your code from the previous level, so use the "Fork" button to copy the previous Pen in your CodePen account:

item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start writing!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, this is a comment. To get started with moderating, editing, and deleting comments, please visit the Comments screen in the dashboard. Commenter avatars come from Gravatar.

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded: You might be an artist who would like to introduce yourself and your work here or maybe you’re a business with a mission to describe.

item.title: Contact
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded: This is a page with some basic contact information, such as an address and phone number. You might also try a plugin to add a contact form.

item.title: A homepage section
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded: This is an example of a homepage section. Homepage sections can be any page other than the homepage itself, including the page that shows your latest blog posts.

item.title: Publish
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded:
Publish

Up till this point, we've been doing all of our development by writing code on CodePen, which calls itself a "social development environment". Since it allows you to write code in the browser and see the results as you go, it's a great tool for learning and trial/error.

However, if you want to publish a real website online you'll need a domain name (e.g. "edincoder.tk", "google.com", "bbc.co.uk") and "web hosting". Web hosting is a service where you pay a hosting company a monthly fee to run internet-connected computers 24/7 (known as "servers"). 

Once you have hosting, you then upload your code to the server run by your hosting company, configure your domain name to point to this server, and the website you've built will be accessible by browsing to your domain name.

In this page, we're going to give you your own hosting and subdomain for free, then show you how to upload your code from CodePen to your hosting.

Step 1

Find an EdinCoder team member and ask them for the pot of hosting account slips.

Pick one (they're all fruits/sweet foods!), and let the EdinCoder team member know which one you've picked so we can record it as taken!

This slip contains the following information for your hosting account:

Website URLcPanel URLUsernamePassword
https://NAME.edincoder.tkhttps://cpanel.NAME.edincoder.tkNAMEcoder**************

"cPanel" is a very popular web hosting control panel - this is the web interface you can log into (with the credentials above) to manage your hosting account.

This hosting account is sponsored by EdinCoder and is free to use indefinitely for learning or personal use - if you end up using one of these to run a successful business/commercial website, we can talk about hosting fees!

The web address which these hosting accounts have been set up with as their "default domain" is a subdomain of the ".edincoder.tk" domain which allows us to set that up for free without much hassle.

If you want to set up your own domain to point to this hosting account instead, you're more than welcome to - there are instructions further down this page.

Step 2

Log into your cPanel account, and familiarise yourself with the interface and some of the features.

It's a very fully-featured control panel so it may be a bit overwhelming. The only bits you'll use for the majority of use cases are in the top three sections - Files, Databases and Domains.

Step 3

Open the cPanel "File Manager" and double-click the "public_html" folder to enter it. 

This is what we call your "web root" - the folder which the server tries to load files from when somebody loads your web address in a browser.

Step 4

Click the  button in the cPanel File Manager, and create a file called "index.html" in your web root.

This filename is the default HTML file which the server tries to load when somebody browses to your domain name without a specific file in the URL.

For example, if you browse to https://NAMEcoder.edincoder.tk/hello.html, the server will try and load a file called "hello.html" in your web root, but if you browse to just https://NAMEcoder.edincoder.tk, the server will try and load "index.html" - this is because historically, websites started with an index page!

Step 5

Click the index.html file once to select it, then click  to open the file in cPanel's web-based text editor. If you get an encoding popup, just click "Edit".

We're going to copy and paste the HTML from codepen into this file to make it live, but first we need to explain a little bit more about the structure of HTML!

At the top level, HTML pages are actually made up of three parts - the "doctype", "head" and "body":

  • DOCTYPE - This used to change how different browsers processed the page, but fortunately we no longer need to worry about it and it's simply "html".
  • head - This is where you set the page title (shown in browser tab), and load any external files (e.g. CSS, JavaScript).
  • body - This is where all of the page structure and content lives, and is what we've been building in the HTML section on CodePen.

As CodePen is designed to let you get started with visual changes as quickly as possible, the HTML editor window is actually just editing the body section.

Therefore, we need to add the rest of the structure to your index.html file before copy/pasting your body code from CodePen.

Copy the following HTML structure into the cPanel editor:

<!DOCTYPE html>

<html lang="en">

<head>

    <meta charset="UTF-8">

    <title>Edincoder: Level Three</title>

    <link type="text/css" rel="stylesheet" href="main.css" />

    <script src="main.js"></script>

</head>

<body>

 

</body>

</html>

Next, copy the HTML content from your most recent CodePen between the opening and closing "body" tags in this file.

Click the  button at the top right of the cPanel file editor to save the HTML file.

Step 6

In the "head" section of our HTML file, you may have noticed a "script" tag with a "src" attribute of "main.js". 

This tells your web browser to fetch the file called "main.js" and execute the code inside. However, we still need to create this file!

Click the  button in the cPanel File Manager, and create a file called "main.js" in your web root.

Click the main.js file once to select it, then click  to open the file in cPanel's web-based text editor. If you get an encoding popup, just click "Edit".

Copy the JavaScript code from your most recent CodePen into the file, and click  at the top right of the cPanel file editor to save the file.

Step 7

In the "head" section of our HTML file, you may have noticed a "link" tag with a "rel" attribute of "stylesheet" and "href" of "main.css". 

This tells your web browser to fetch the file called "main.css" and apply it to the page as a stylesheet. However, we still need to create this file!

Click the  button in the cPanel File Manager, and create a file called "main.css" in your web root.

Click the main.css file once to select it, then click  to open the file in cPanel's web-based text editor. If you get an encoding popup, just click "Edit".

Copy the CSS code from your most recent CodePen into the file, and click  at the top right of the cPanel file editor to save the file.

Step 8

Load your web address in a browser tab and check it all works as expected - it should be the same as on CodePen, but now properly hosted!

Congratulations, you've now published your own online networking / professional profile page online - share the address with friends and family!

Custom Domain Name

If you'd like to use your own domain name instead of the .edincoder.tk subdomain we've set up for you, here's how to do that.

Browse to http://www.dot.tk, a domain name registrar offering domain names at the following top-level domains: .tk, .ml, .ga, .cf, .gq. free for up to 1 year.

If you want a domain name with a more common TLD (e.g. .co.uk, .com), you can follow the same process but will need to pay a yearly fee of £3-£15.

Search for a name of your choice to find one which is available:

Proceed to the checkout, select a period of 12 Months, click "Use DNS" and enter the following nameservers: "ns1.techfixuk.com", "ns2.techfixuk.com"

Continue through the checkout process with freenom - you'll need to verify your email address and enter name/address etc.

Once complete, you now own your own domain name, and because you've set it up to point at our nameservers, you can then link this domain in cPanel:

Log into your hosting control panel, and click the  button. 

Enter your domain name and click "Add Domain" - you've now linked this domain to your hosting account and can use it instead of "NAME.edincoder.tk".

Course Complete!

Congratulations, you've completed the EdinCoder course! 

You've learned the basics of HTML, CSS and JavaScript, and have published your own website online.

Hopefully you now understand more about how the web works, and perhaps you've discovered coding can be enjoyable!

The website you've now published online is yours to do whatever you like with - perhaps there's some functionality you'd like to add to it yourself?

If you've reached this point before the end of the time slot for this session, we're very happy to help show you how to implement anything you want!

If you'd like to continue learning more and practicing your new skills, thankfully there are a huge number of resources available online.

Resources

item.title: Resources
item.dc:creator: edincoder
item.content:encoded:
Learning resources for coders

The tech industry is thankfully not precious about sharing knowledge, and is naturally well stocked with people who know how to publish a website online!

As a result, there are a huge number of tutorials, courses and communities available online, covering many languages, technologies and niches. If you are keen to start exploring more technologies and continue learning, we recommend searching the internet for tutorials and documentation about what interests you - Google is your friend!

However, it can be hard to know what to look for when you're just getting started. 

To help mitigate this, we've compiled lists of our favourite resources and grouped them into categories. Every developer should probably be familiar with at least one resource from each category. 

These lists are far from exhaustive - rather, we hope to give you an idea of what is out there to get you started!

Training and Courses

There are loads of structured learning courses available online that cover pretty much anything you could ever want to learn about coding.

These are probably the easiest way to start learning, as they'll guide you through the whole process of learning a topic using a variety of learning styles - reading, writing real code to complete tasks, watching videos, etc.

Here are a few to try out that are tried, tested and loved by our team.

Specific Topics / Concepts

Whilst the online courses are structured to take you through the process of learning an entire topic, there are also some very good online resources which don’t fit into this format of “course”.

Some of these are still incredibly valuable resources though, so are worth checking out for learning about specific topics or use as reference guides.

Coding Practice

Once you’ve completed a course or tutorial designed to teach you a particular language or technology, you need to practice actually using that technology in order to solidify your new knowledge and gain confidence in your ability to use it for real work.

Thankfully there are a variety of high quality sites designed to provide exactly that – challenges and practice problems for you to complete, some with competitive elements or the potential to directly lead to job offers once you’ve proven your ability to code!

Support Communities

There are a number of both global and local communities that you can become a part of, to help you flourish as an amazing software developer.

Joining at least one community so you have a support network of people to talk to, ask for help and potentially meet up with regularly can have a really significant impact on your learning experience!

Code Editors

During this course we used CodePen to write code online in the web browser, but typically software engineers will write code directly on their computer using a text editor such as Atom, or an IDE (Integrated Development Environment) such as WebStorm - these offer a variety of features to make it easier to write code (e.g. auto-completion and indentation).

There are also various online code editors available - these can help especially when you're learning to code, as you don't need to install anything and can access your code from any computer connected to the internet, allowing you to keep practicing wherever you are!

Home
