Some of these are still incredibly valuable resources though, so are worth checking out for learning about specific topics or use as reference guides.<\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"0d19b0d","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"0dcb337","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100},"elements":[{"id":"5589149","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"divider"},{"id":"7e6863b","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20"},"elements":[{"id":"b0e7dee","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":40,"content_position":"center"},"elements":[{"id":"ee9e3d8","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/edincoder.tk\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/02\/coding-practice-resources.png","id":761},"title_text":"Coding Practice","description_text":"","link":{"url":"\/coding-practice-resources\/","is_external":"","nofollow":""},"image_size":{"unit":"%","size":50}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image-box"}],"isInner":true},{"id":"0d06482","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":60,"content_position":"center"},"elements":[{"id":"9778faf","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Once you\u2019ve completed a course or tutorial designed to teach you a particular language or technology, you need to practice actually using that technology in order to solidify your new knowledge and gain confidence in your ability to use it for real work.<\/p>

Thankfully there are a variety of high quality sites designed to provide exactly that \u2013 challenges and practice problems for you to complete, some with competitive elements or the potential to directly lead to job offers once you\u2019ve proven your ability to code!<\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"e750994","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"69fb2ed","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100},"elements":[{"id":"b6bdbd2","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"divider"},{"id":"b394bcd","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20"},"elements":[{"id":"7f70f30","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":40,"content_position":"center"},"elements":[{"id":"0d80038","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/edincoder.tk\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/02\/support-communities.png","id":763},"title_text":"Support Communities","description_text":"","link":{"url":"\/support-communities\/","is_external":"","nofollow":""},"image_size":{"unit":"%","size":50}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image-box"}],"isInner":true},{"id":"a5ec083","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":60,"content_position":"center"},"elements":[{"id":"3fb23b4","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

There are a number of both global and local communities that you can become a part of, to help you flourish as an amazing software developer.<\/p>

Joining at least one community so you have a support network of people to talk to, ask for help and potentially meet up with regularly can have a really significant impact on your learning experience!<\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"7289302","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"c9ca602","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100},"elements":[{"id":"49942dd","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"divider"},{"id":"55f6e99","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20"},"elements":[{"id":"8c84550","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":40,"content_position":"center"},"elements":[{"id":"0e928a7","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/edincoder.tk\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/02\/code-editors.png","id":772},"title_text":"Code Editors","description_text":"","link":{"url":"\/code-editors\/","is_external":"","nofollow":""},"image_size":{"unit":"%","size":50}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image-box"}],"isInner":true},{"id":"5fcc344","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":60,"content_position":"center"},"elements":[{"id":"08b4f11","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

During this course we used CodePen<\/a> to write code online in the web browser, but typically software engineers will write code directly on their computer using a\u00a0text editor such as<\/span>\u00a0<\/span>Atom<\/a>, or an IDE (Integrated Development Environment) such as WebStorm<\/a>\u00a0- these offer a variety of features to make it easier to write code (e.g. auto-completion and indentation).<\/p>

There are also\u00a0various online code editors available<\/span>\u00a0<\/span>- these can help especially when you're learning to code, as you don't need to install anything and can access your code from any computer connected to the internet, allowing you to keep practicing wherever you are!<\/span><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"55e9a226","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"71bc7b0d","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100},"elements":[{"id":"124d1af7","elType":"widget","settings":{"button_type":"info","text":"Home","link":{"url":"\/","is_external":"","nofollow":""},"align":"left","size":"md","icon":"fa fa-arrow-circle-left","icon_indent":{"unit":"px","size":15},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"50","right":"0","bottom":"100","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"button"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]

item.title: Specific Topic Resources
item.dc:creator: nat
item.content:encoded:
Specific Topic / Concept Resources

Whilst the online courses are structured to take you through the process of learning an entire topic, there are also some very good online resources which don’t fit into this format of “course”.

Some of these are still incredibly valuable resources though, so are worth checking out for learning about specific topics or use as reference guides.

Learn Enough to be Dangerous

  • Command Line
  • Text Editor
  • Git
  • HTML, CSS and Layout
  • JavaScript
  • Ruby
  • The Rails Tutorial
  • Action Cable

w3schools

  • Tutorials
  • References
  • Examples

Brilliant.org

  • Algorithms
  • Recursion
  • Stacks and Queues
  • Binary Trees
  • Heaps

Source Making

  • Design Patterns
  • AntiPatterns
  • Refactoring
  • UML

Cloud Computing Patterns

  • Cloud Computing Fundamentals
  • Cloud Offerings
  • Cloud Application Architectures
  • Cloud Application Management
  • Composite Cloud Applications
Learning Resources

item.title: Interview Preparation
item.dc:creator: nat

item.title: Training and Courses
item.dc:creator: nat
item.content:encoded:
Training and Courses

There are loads of structured learning courses available online that cover pretty much anything you could ever want to learn about coding.

These are probably the easiest way to start learning, as they'll guide you through the whole process of learning a topic using a variety of learning styles - reading, writing real code to complete tasks, watching videos, etc.

Here are a few to try out that are tried, tested and loved by our team.

Codecademy

There are separate courses for each language, divided into chapters to explain specific concepts and give you a bit of practice. You can edit the sample code and see the results immediately. Completing an exercise unlocks the next chapter, and after each course you can test your knowledge with a quiz.

Free Code Camp

Courses are broken down into challenges. Each challenge gives you a new feature or command to learn and a piece of code that you can amend and see the changes on a little mobile phone on the website which displays your application. You are given a list of requests that your app must meet, and you need to change the code accordingly.

edX

Huge database of over 500 courses related with Computer Science prepared by universities from all over the world. You can learn programming, using software and acquire technical skills. These courses are a great source of theoretical knowledge, but they do not allow for much practice.

Future Learn

Various courses about Tech and Coding. They focus on computer science rather than programming. Courses are not interactive but provide a lot of knowledge. Not a good place for someone who wants to discover basics of coding.

Khan Academy

Lessons start with short introduction article followed by videos which explain the code. In each chapter there are quizzes and practical challenges to test your progress. Lessons have great documentation where functions are commands are well explained.

Upskill

Step by step how to create your website. It explains also how to set up a cloud and turn it into a server to host your website. Great course for beginners, however lessons are based on videos and there is not much room for practice.

Udemy

Most of the courses are not free. Lessons are based on videos and they do not provide any practice or exercises.

Resource Comparison

Account Required

Codecademy freeCodeCamp edX Future Learn Khan Academy Upskill Udemy
Yes No Yes Yes Required if you want to keep projects Yes for some lessons No

Cost

Codecademy freeCodeCamp edX Future Learn Khan Academy Upskill Udemy
Free, with paid upgrade to Pro available Free, donations possible Free Free Free Free Some free, others paid

Languages / Courses

Codecademy freeCodeCamp edX Future Learn Khan Academy Upskill Udemy
HTML, CSS, PHP, Python, JavaScript, Java, SQL, Bash/Shell, Ruby HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, Databases, Git, GitHub, Node.js, React.js, D3.js HTML5, CSS, Node.js, C#, C++, Java, JavaScript, Python, SQL, +more Web Analytics, Beginner Robotics, Game Design, Social Media JavaScript, HTML, CSS, SQL HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Ruby, Rails JavaScript, HTML, CSS, C#, Android, Development, Python, Web Design, AngularJS, GitHub, +more

Level

Codecademy freeCodeCamp edX Future Learn Khan Academy Upskill Udemy
Beginner Beginner, Intermediate, Advanced Beginner, Intermediate, Advanced Unspecified Beginner, Advanced Beginner Beginner, Intermediate
Learning Resources

item.title: Coding Practice Resources
item.dc:creator: beveradb
item.content:encoded:
Coding Practice Resources

Once you've completed a course or tutorial designed to teach you a particular language or technology, you need to practice actually using that technology in order to solidify your new knowledge and gain confidence in your ability to use it for real work.

Thankfully there are a variety of high quality sites designed to provide exactly that - challenges and practice problems for you to complete, some with competitive elements or the potential to directly lead to job offers once you've proven your ability to code!

Glitch

"Glitch is the friendly community where you'll build the app of your dreams"

"With working example apps to remix, a code editor to modify them, instant hosting and deployment - anybody can build a web app on Glitch, for free.

You never have to start from a blank slate. Remix a full, working app to personalize it for your needs, or build on the most popular and powerful developer frameworks to create your app."

Mozilla Thimble

"Write the Web, On the Web

Thimble is a full-featured code editor that runs right in the browser. It's designed to help new coders create their own sites and web-based projects using HTML, CSS & JavaScript. Everything you need is at your fingertips, allowing you (or your classroom) to get up and running as quickly as possible.

It's a code editor, web server, web browser & developer tools all in one—and it's free!"

CodeWars

"Achieve mastery through challenge"

"Challenge yourself on kata, created by the community to strengthen different skills. Master your current language of choice, or expand your understanding of a new one.

Kata are ranked to approximate difficulty. As you complete higher ranked kata, you progress through the ranks so we can match you with relevant challenges.

Compare your solution with others after each kata for greater understanding."

Exercism

"Level up your programming skills"

"Exercism provides countless small wins. The exercises are achievable mini-quests: small and well-defined, and with enough complexity to uncover bite-sized knowledge gaps.

The solutions you write provide reviewers with clues about what you haven't grasped yet. The feedback you receive will guide you to relevant study topics and dramatically increase the ease with which you write code."

Project Euler

"Project Euler is a series of challenging mathematical/computer programming problems that will require more than just mathematical insights to solve. 

Although mathematics will help you arrive at elegant and efficient methods, the use of a computer and programming skills will be required to solve most problems."

HackerRank

"Practice, Compete, Find Jobs

The HackerRank Community is the largest learning and competition community for programmers

The HackerRank team is on a mission to match every developer in the world to the right job by providing a technical recruiting platform that assesses developers based on actual coding skills."

TestDome

"Practice interview questions and get certified for free.

Score well on one of our public tests and you will get a free certificate of achievement."

Learning Resources

item.title: Support Communities
item.dc:creator: kim
item.content:encoded:
Support Communities

There are a number of both global and local communities that you can become a part of, to help you flourish as an amazing software developer.

Joining at least one community so you have a support network of people to talk to, ask for help and potentially meet up with regularly can have a really significant impact on your learning experience! 

Women Who Code

Women Who Code are a global organisation who are dedicated to getting more women into the tech field. They currently have an Edinburgh local meetup group who run monthly talks and networking events. These talks aim to build up both the technical and soft skills of their members.

If you're interested in attending any of their events, check out their website or page on meetup.

codebar

Codebar is a free volunteer run organisation that run monthly workshops teaching people to code. They aim to provide 1 on 1 mentoring time from their amazing coaches. They teach a variety of tutorials in HTML, CSS, JavaScript and Ruby, but are open to helping connect you with a coach who can help with other languages that you may be interested in.

If you're interested in attending then check out their Edinburgh group.

#CodeNewbie

#CodeNewbie are an online community who aim to support people on their continued journey to being a software developer. They encourage people to check in, motivate and help one another. They have a massively supportive network available to help people online on both Facebook and Twitter.

Check out their website to join in their challenges and #100DaysOfCode

Local Tech Meetups

There are regular meetups of people working in the software development industry in most major cities. In tech hubs such as Edinburgh or London, you'll probably be able to find multiple tech meetups for each specific niche (e.g. specific language or tool of your choice).

Attending these can help you learn things you'd never have thought to learn about, and connect you with like-minded people. It's also great to mention attending these on your CV!

To find meetups, you can search on sites such as Meetup.com, or use the handy Open Tech Calendar website which collates Tech-specific meetups in many UK towns/cities.

Learning Resources

item.title: Level 4
item.dc:creator: beveradb
item.content:encoded:
Level 4

In this level we're going to make the "Hire Me" button a bit nicer, with a simple name / email / message form in a popup.

To do this, we'll add a bit more HTML and CSS for a form in a popup, then write some JavaScript to implement the functionality.

---------------------------------------------

Sorry, we haven't finished writing the steps for this level yet! 

If you'd like to give it a try anyway, you can access our (finished) implementation example here:

Level 4 Example Demo

This allows you to view the source code by right-clicking the page and selecting "View Source", so even if you're not comfortable doing this yourself without guidance yet, you can read through the code we've written and try to make sense of it. If you get this far, let us know so we can come and talk you through it!

Screenshot:

item.title: Code Editors
item.dc:creator: beveradb
item.content:encoded:
Code Editors

During this course we used CodePen to write code online in the web browser, but typically software engineers will write code directly on their computer using a text editor such as Atom, or an IDE (Integrated Development Environment) such as WebStorm - these offer a variety of features to make it easier to write code (e.g. auto-completion and indentation).

There are also various online code editors available - these can help especially when you're learning to code, as you don't need to install anything and can access your code from any computer connected to the internet, allowing you to keep practicing wherever you are!

Atom

"At GitHub, we're building the text editor we've always wanted. A tool you can customize to do anything, but also use productively on the first day without ever touching a config file. Atom is modern, approachable, and hackable to the core. We can't wait to see what you build with it."

WebStorm

"WebStorm is a lightweight and intelligent IDE for front-end development and server-side JavaScript."

WebStorm is one of many fully-featured IDEs (Integrated Development Environment) built by JetBrains, a company who produce premium software development tools used by millions of developers. WebStorm in particular (as opposed to PHPStorm, PyCharm, RubyMine etc.) is focused on web development using server-side JavaScript (Node.js).

Vim

Vim is an advanced text editor which is used directly from the command line / terminal, so is highly popular amongst engineers who enjoy working from a command prompt rather than using software with a graphical user interface.

Vim is a highly configurable text editor built to enable efficient text editing. It is an improved version of the vi editor distributed with most UNIX systems. Vim is distributed free as charityware.

Sublime Text

Sublime Text is available for OS X, Windows and Linux. One license is all you need to use Sublime Text on every computer you own, no matter what operating system it uses. 

Sublime Text uses a custom UI toolkit, optimized for speed and beauty, while taking advantage of native functionality on each platform.

Codepen

CodePen is the HTML/CSS/JavaScript editor we have been using in this course.

"CodePen is a social development environment. At its heart, it allows you to write code in the browser, and see the results of it as you build."

Other Online Code Editors

JsFiddle

Similar to CodePen, this is an HTML/CSS/JavaScript editor

CodePad

While CodePad has a reduced user interface, it has many more languages available, including PHP, Python, and Ruby.

LiveWeave

Similar to CodePen and jsfiddle, this is a HTML/CSS/JavaScript editor

CodeSandbox

This editor is for JavaScript web development and can be used with languages like React and Vue.

Learning Resources
